title: Getting Started with Claude for Building Apps
description: Learn what Claude is, set up your environment, and write your first app-building prompt that produces a runnable starter project.
learningObjectives: Understand what Claude is and what 'AI-assisted product building' means for non-programmers
Set up the minimum environment required to follow the course (accounts/tools)
Write and refine a first 'app-building prompt' that produces a runnable starter project

videos.title: What Claude Is (and Isn't) for Building Products
videos.description: Clarifies Claude's strengths and limitations, and how to think about it as a building partner for non-programmers.
scriptOutline: What is Claude? (AI assistant by Anthropic)
What Claude can do: generate code, explain concepts, iterate on ideas
What Claude can't do: run code for you, deploy apps, access the internet (without tools)
Mindset shift: Claude as a collaborator, not a magic button
talkingPoints: Think of Claude as a very smart intern who can code — you provide direction, it executes
You don't need to understand the code; you need to understand what you want
Iteration is key: your first prompt won't be perfect, and that's okay

videos.title: Setup Checklist: Accounts, Workspace, and Safety Basics
videos.description: Walks through required accounts/tools and safe practices for working with AI-generated code.
scriptOutline: Recommended: Claude Pro for extended usage
Basic workspace setup: where to save prompts and outputs
Safety basics: don't share API keys, verify code before running
talkingPoints: You only need a Claude account to get started — nothing else required today
Golden rule: always read what Claude generates before running it

videos.title: Your First Build Prompt: From Idea → Starter App Plan
videos.description: Demonstrates a prompt structure that yields a project plan, file list, and step-by-step build instructions.
scriptOutline: Anatomy of a good 'build prompt': goal, constraints, tech preference, success criteria
Live demo: writing a prompt for a simple app idea
Reviewing Claude's response: what to look for
Quick iteration: making one improvement to the prompt
talkingPoints: A good prompt has four parts: what you want, what constraints exist, what tech to use, and how you'll know it worked
Always ask Claude to 'ask clarifying questions first' — this improves output quality
Don't accept the first response; one round of iteration makes a big difference

textSections.title: Prompt Skeleton for Beginners
textSections.content:
I want to build [app type] that helps [user] to [solve problem].

Constraints:
- [Constraint 1]
- [Constraint 2]

Tech preference: [e.g., 'something simple I can run in a browser' or 'no preference']

Success criteria:
- [Criterion 1]
- [Criterion 2]

Before generating anything, please ask me clarifying questions.

textSections.title: Key Definitions
textSections.content:
**Prompt:** The instructions you give to Claude

**Iteration:** Refining your prompt or Claude's output through multiple rounds

**Artifact:** A file or piece of code Claude generates for you

commonMistakes.explanation: 'Make me an app' gives poor results. Be specific about the problem and user.
Always iterate at least once; ask Claude to improve or clarify.
Running code without understanding what it does can cause problems.
Start with something tiny (1-2 features max).

reflectionQuestions: What part of using Claude felt most unclear: setup, prompting, or understanding outputs?
What's one thing you'd change about your first prompt now that you've seen Claude's response?

exercises.title: Create Your Project Brief
exercises.description: Write a one-page brief for a tiny app idea you want to build.
exercises.output: Document containing: problem statement, target user, 3 features max, success criteria
successCriteria: Features are limited to 3 or fewer

exercises.title: Write Your First Claude Build Prompt
exercises.description: Using the prompt skeleton provided, write a complete prompt for your app idea.
exercises.output: A saved prompt document ready to paste into Claude
successCriteria: All four sections filled in (goal, constraints, tech, success criteria)
Specific enough that another person could understand your app idea

exercises.title: Run Your Prompt and Capture Outputs
exercises.description: Paste your prompt into Claude, answer any clarifying questions, and capture the results.
exercises.output: Document containing: Claude's clarifying questions + your answers, project plan, file list, first-step instructions
exercises.successCriteria: Open-ended exploration: Reflect on what surprised you about Claude's response.

instructorNotes: For live sessions: Have learners share their app ideas with a partner before writing prompts — peer feedback improves prompt quality.
Common questions: 'Can Claude actually make my app work?' — Reassure that this lesson is about planning; running code comes later.
Self-paced tip: Encourage learners to screenshot their Claude conversation for later reference.
Time check: Exercise 3 often takes longer than expected; consider making it optional homework for time-constrained sessions.
